009package imagingbook.common.geometry.ellipse.project;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012import static java.lang.Math.sqrt;
013
014import imagingbook.common.geometry.ellipse.GeometricEllipse;
015
016/**
017 * <p>
018 * Calculates an approximate closest point on the ellipse for a given 2D point inside
019 * or outside the ellipse, using "confocal conic distance approximation" [1].
020 * See Sec. 11.2.3 (Alg. 11.12) and Appendix F.3.1 of [2] for details.
021 * </p>
022 * <p>
023 * [1] P. L. Rosin. Ellipse fitting using orthogonal hyperbolae and stirling’s
024 * oval. Graphical Models and Image Processing 60(3), 209–213 (1998). <br>
025 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
026 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
027 * </p>
028 * 
029 * @author WB
030 * @version 2022/11/17
031 */
032public class ConfocalConicEllipseProjector extends EllipseProjector {
033        
034        private final double ra, rb, ra2, rb2;
035        
036        public ConfocalConicEllipseProjector(GeometricEllipse ellipse) {
037                super(ellipse);
038                this.ra = ellipse.ra;
039                this.rb = ellipse.rb;
040                this.ra2 = sqr(ra);
041                this.rb2 = sqr(rb);
042        }
043        
044        // ellipse projection in quadrant 1 of u/v space
045        @Override
046        protected double[] projectCanonical(double[] uv) {
047                // uv is supposed to be in quadrant 1 of canonical frame
048                double u = uv[0];
049                double v = uv[1];
050                double u2 = sqr(u);
051                double v2 = sqr(v);
052                double fe2 = ra2 - rb2;
053                double b = (u2 + v2 + fe2);
054                double sa2 = 0.5 * (b - sqrt(sqr(b) - 4 * u2 * fe2));
055                double sb2 = fe2 - sa2; 
056                double c = 1 / sqrt(ra2 * sb2 + rb2 * sa2);     
057                return new double[] {c * ra * sqrt(sa2 * (rb2 + sb2)), c * rb * sqrt(sb2 * (ra2 - sa2))};
058        }
059        
060}
